context:
Program Name: Autism and Behavioural Science
Code: C405
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 1 year (2 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,832.00
International Tuition: $17,845.00
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Health & Wellness
Location: Waterfront Campus
Delivery (Fall 2023): Hybrid (Semester 1) and Hybrid (Semesters 1 and 2)
Program Description: A postgraduate program focusing on autism spectrum disorders and therapies, mainly Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), with a primary application for children and adolescents. Enables graduates to gain practical experience working with treatment teams.
Development Background: Created to deepen expertise in the field of autism and behavioural sciences for application within the children's sector and to meet the needs of service agencies providing autism or children's services.

The Autism and Behavioural Science program at the college is designed for graduates with university degrees and those from Early Childhood Education, Social Service Worker, Child and Youth Care, Developmental Service Worker, and similar programs. The program equips graduates with specialized skills and expertise to work with individuals diagnosed with autism.

Students will learn about Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), intervention methods such as Intensive Behavioural Intervention (IBI) and Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA), relevant legislation, and working with families and treatment teams. Field education may require travel to various locations within the Greater Toronto Area (GTA).

Recommended skills for this career path include being caring, tenacious, analytic, and detail-oriented. The program features full-time and part-time faculty with extensive experience in ABA, IBI, and ASD. It also has well-established relationships with agencies providing services for individuals with autism.

Field placement experiences include observing an individual with autism during semester 1 (three weeks) and identifying a target behavior and developing a treatment plan during semester 2 (seven weeks). Graduates may find employment as instructor-therapists in agencies offering ABA for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder, schools, or private family settings. Career opportunities also include becoming a resource teacher, educational assistant, or program supervisor.

Required courses are not specified in the provided text.

Program Offered: Behavioural Science (BST) with a focus on Applied Behaviour Analysis for individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorders

Semester 1 Courses:
- BST 1101: Introduction to Applied Behaviour Analysis
- BST 1102: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorders
- BST 1104: Working with Families and Teams
- BST 1105: Ethics & Professionalism
- BST 1106: Field Placement I
- BST 1108: Field Seminar I
- BST 1121: Behavioural Skill Building

Semester 2 Courses:
- BST 1103: Treating Challenging Behaviour
- BST 1122: Parent and Staff Training
- BST 1123: Specialized Instructional Strategies
- BST 1124: Transition Planning and Implementation
- BST 1125: Field Placement II
- BST 1126: Field Work Seminar II

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Assess and analyze the characteristics, skills and behaviour of individuals with ASD to effectively implement evidence-based behavioural interventions.
2. Design and implement effective behavioural intervention plans under appropriate supervision and based on the principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA).
3. Evaluate the effectiveness of behavioural intervention plans based on the principles of ABA.
4. Work collaboratively with families, teams, service providers and the broader community to respond to the learning and behavioural needs of individuals with ASD.
5. Design, implement and evaluate as part of a team ABA-based transition plans for individuals with ASD.
6. Comply with established ethical principles and professional guidelines.
7. Provide leadership in the promotion and provision of services to meet the needs of individuals with ASD and their families.
8. Evaluate empirical evidence in order to select appropriate interventions for individuals with ASD.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Students: $3,832.00 (first two semesters)
- International Students: $17,845.00 (first two semesters)

question: , Which courses are offered in Semester 1 for BST program?

context:
Program Offered: Behavioural Science (BST) with a focus on Applied Behaviour Analysis for individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorders

Semester 1 Courses:
- BST 1101: Introduction to Applied Behaviour Analysis
- BST 1102: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorders
- BST 1104: Working with Families and Teams
- BST 1105: Ethics & Professionalism
- BST 1106: Field Placement I
- BST 1108: Field Seminar I
- BST 1121: Behavioural Skill Building

Semester 2 Courses:
- BST 1103: Treating Challenging Behaviour
- BST 1122: Parent and Staff Training
- BST 1123: Specialized Instructional Strategies
- BST 1124: Transition Planning and Implementation
- BST 1125: Field Placement II
- BST 1126: Field Work Seminar II

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Assess and analyze the characteristics, skills and behaviour of individuals with ASD to effectively implement evidence-based behavioural interventions.
2. Design and implement effective behavioural intervention plans under appropriate supervision and based on the principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA).
3. Evaluate the effectiveness of behavioural intervention plans based on the principles of ABA.
4. Work collaboratively with families, teams, service providers and the broader community to respond to the learning and behavioural needs of individuals with ASD.
5. Design, implement and evaluate as part of a team ABA-based transition plans for individuals with ASD.
6. Comply with established ethical principles and professional guidelines.
7. Provide leadership in the promotion and provision of services to meet the needs of individuals with ASD and their families.
8. Evaluate empirical evidence in order to select appropriate interventions for individuals with ASD.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Students: $3,832.00 (first two semesters)
- International Students: $17,845.00 (first two semesters)

Program Information:
- Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
- International Students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
- Financial Assistance is available, but applicants must meet OSAP eligibility criteria.
- Completion of a three-year or four-year Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science degree is required, no specific major is necessary but a major in psychology or related discipline is recommended. Alternatively, a two-year or three-year diploma in a human services discipline with a major in psychology is also acceptable.
- English Language Proficiency tests are required for international applicants without English proficiency test results.
- College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions. International admission requirements can be found on the International Admissions page.
- Students must meet George Brown College pre-placement student health passport requirements before attending a field placement.
- A Police Vulnerable Sector Check is required and must be renewed annually before entering into field or clinical placement.

Mandatory Requirements:
- Pre-placement Health Form: Upon acceptance, students must meet all mandatory pre-placement health requirements for the program. It may take up to four months to complete all the requirements and all costs are the responsibility of the student.
- Police Vulnerable Sector Check: Required for all students in the program and must be renewed annually before entering into field or clinical placement. The process typically takes two to [redacted] days.

The Police Vulnerable Sector Check process takes between two to three months, but can take up to eight months. Students are required to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check to start their field or clinical placement and complete the program. Failure to meet this requirement may prevent students from finishing the program and securing employment. The fees for the police record check vary and are paid by the student. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Public health recommends that students working with young children and other vulnerable communities be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete the field placement component of their program in a timely manner. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For more information, contact the George Brown School of Health and Wellness at 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or email hwprograms@georgebrown.ca. There are related programs offered by George Brown College including the Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302) and Practical Nursing (PN) (S121).
